We are trying to figure out what we should do about it going forward. Just to give you three numbers, we collected $600 million in insurance. They disputed $200 million. The government called that a fraud. We reimbursed $600 million to get out of the lawsuit because it was a threatening lawsuit even though in my opinion it was a commercial dispute between FHA and ourselves about that. And the whole time FHA collected another $1.8 billion in premium. So the real question to me is should we be in the FHA business at all and we are still struggling with that. We want to help the consumers there but we can't do it at great risk to JPMorgan so until they come up with some kind of safe harbors or something, we are going to be very, very cautious in that line of business.
JAMIE DIMON: I think it has slowed down a little.
MARIANNE LAKE: It went down slightly I think.
JAMIE DIMON: Remember, you are talking about different borrowers (inaudible) so it might be something that was two million deposits and some start to borrow money but in general, you are right.
MARIANNE LAKE: So if you look at commercial just as an illustration of your point, what we have got going on is utilization rates in the last few quarters have picked up by 3 points. They are at 33% still much, much lower than you would expect them to be over time which would be slightly above 40%. But you do see deposits flattening out. In fact, there is a little bit of decline. It is not absolutely the case at this point that we can say people are starting to spend their deposits and utilize their lines. As Jamie said, CapEx is still not really out there but that is what you would expect and in this business we did not see strong growth in deposits.
MARIANNE LAKE: First of all, just to make a conceptual point which is we didn't have a target for loan deposits. We were just trying to make the point that obviously as we think forward to the impact of interest rates on our performance over time, we would expect both a mix shift in deposits back towards interest earning and CDs but also expect to see the economy growing and loans growing and that needed to be taken into consideration. So it wasn't really a target, it was just a simulation to start with that. But it was based loosely on levels that we have seen at least in part the cycle that we were referring to. And then you are right, there is a dynamic where because of LTR, we will always have a -- because of our liquidity requirements internally as well, we will have liquid assets that will be structurally higher than they would had previously been and therefore from a mix perspective, that would have an impact. But at this point given where loan to deposits are, I think that would be a high class problem to be talking about.
JAMIE DIMON: Remember there are some unused lines so there is not a loan on the balance sheet that still 100% LCR. So what's really going to happen is it is going to be done at the client level -- capital, LCR, commitments, etc, that is where you are really going to have to manage it, the capital level, the desk level, etc.
JAMIE DIMON: What we have seen a little bit of is trade finance cost have gone up, a little bit in municipal businesses and there you have seen a little bit more restructuring on the type of business people do. Remember some of the repricing may not take place in the product, it may take place in the relationship because all products have loss leaders, etc. But we haven't seen a huge amount of repricing taking place yet.
MARIANNE LAKE: I think if you think about --.
JAMIE DIMON: I have heard some complaints by the way that some of the revolvers are smaller and shorter. It is not the price as much as it is the sizing. And then you have heard some commentary in the market that inventories -- bonds are lower and spreads will gap out so you are starting to see some of it but eventually -- I have never seen a business where the cost of goods sold doesn't eventually get priced in the business. It doesn't have to be priced into the eggs and the milk, it just has to be priced in the transaction, the whole bag the person walks out of the supermarket with.
MARIANNE LAKE: I think one way to look at it is to say while we are absolutely managing through this complex environment, Basel III Tier 1 common still is our binding constraint at the margin, that is how we allocate capital to the businesses and that is the sort of primary lend that we are using to price. And what you are going to see, as Jamie talked about, is that the leverage and LCR and other constraints including stressed capital are going to play out at the client level as we just are becoming more efficient at how we deploy our balance sheet rather than necessarily a repricing strategy.
JAMIE DIMON: And CCar, we are pushing CCAR down. To the extent we can, we are going to push CCAR down to those things which create CCAR-ness.
JAMIE DIMON: I wouldn't hold your breath. Some people are leaving businesses, some are optimizing decline levels, some are having strategic changes and it will happen over time and we are quite patient about it. We are in no rush. We're not going to try to lead it or anything like that. It will happen over time. Like I said, you have seen it in trade finance, you've seen it in certain municipal businesses, you have seen it in -and all the rules aren't final. When the rules become final, people may react differently.
MARIANNE LAKE: Yes, the improvement at the bank and the holding company was retained earnings, [pressed] net of capital distributions but we continue to work through all of the other initiatives we have to optimize leverage including compression trades and pair ups and the like. That is actually happening a little bit more slowly than we had thought just broadly in the industry. It still presents an opportunity, it is not the most sizable opportunity but we are diligently getting after it. And then with respect to (inaudible), we estimated clearly it is a complex calculation so we will be slightly wrong in our estimate. We estimated it to have a benefit for the firm of 30 basis points and for the bank at 40 basis points. Yes, we would expect that at some point it would be ultimately adopted by the US regulators but that doesn't look like it expects to be helping our numbers this year or next.
MARIANNE LAKE: It is essentially cyclical. I mean I wish we could actively manage it down because it is positive (inaudible) calculation but the truth of the matter is it is a factor of activity levels.
MARIANNE LAKE: We don't think it is significant.
JAMIE DIMON: So CRA, remember is a combination of lower and middle income mortgages so we will obviously try to meet those commitments. It includes how many branches you have in lower and middle income so we will continue to build that. It is a function of CDFI, like lending to small business or community development funds which we will continue to do. So it runs a whole gamut and we will meet our CRA commitment. Yes if you don't do in the FHA, it hurts you a little bit but to do FHA. lose billions of dollars that is a whole different level of shareholder responsibility and so we've got to be very careful how we handle that. I am hoping FHA comes forth and comes up with some real bright lines and harbors to make it easy for us to try to do what the government wants us to do but we can't get penalized severely for some of the things that happen.
JAMIE DIMON: It is all of that. We are going to meet CRA. We report CRA to our sellers every month and like I said, it cuts across a wide variety of things that we do for people and we just did this great thing in Detroit that is a lot of CRA credits. We can you mortgages ourselves that we can put on balance sheet that we think are less risky than FHA insurance. So we will figure it out. We are just thoroughly, thoroughly confused about how we got treated, how we've got it going forward and we are kind of waiting for -- we have spoken to government for some kind of guidance going forward.
JAMIE DIMON: Yes.
MARIANNE LAKE: It's deals and reps and warrants.
JAMIE DIMON: It is the reps and warrants that there should be a commercial resolution of the dispute but you don't have [treble] damages if something goes wrong.
MARIANNE LAKE: Thank you.

JAMIE DIMON, CEO, JPMORGAN CHASE & CO.: So let me just give a couple of overall comments before we take some questions. Obviously, we necessarily need to be prepared for a bad environment. We don't know what the environment is going to be. Mike took you through all the credit numbers. If you look at them, other than home lending, which we think is far worse than we would have expected, we're actually not that bad, non-performers, delinquencies in Card, et cetera, but when you see this kind of unemployment, this contained of uncertainty, the reduced consumer spend, we are getting braced for increasing loan loss reserves going forward. So it's reasonable as a shareholder if you'll expect that trade results can be very tough forward, that charge-offs are going to be going up, that loan losses will be added at least the next couple quarters. But we're going into an environment with an extremely strong balance sheet, 8.9% Tier 1 before the government's addition to that, very strong loan losses or leading among the strongest in the industry, which probably will be strengthened going forward. And I think of note when you go through this press release, there is real growth. In some areas it's in market share like investment banking and mortgages, even though it's a tough business, in other areas it's really broad growth in deposits and loans and you see that in TSS, the Private Bank, and the Commercial Bank, so we feel pretty good about it. Even in the Card business where we have kind of low expectations for spend, our spend is up 5%, and from what we know Visa numbers are more like zero. So we seem to be gaining a little bit of share there too. I want to point out in the Investment Bank, one of the things -- if you back out losses, which we don't think you should do, but the trading results were pretty good. But another way to view that is based on what we just went through in September, and obviously for the whole quarter, but September in particular, you've got to feel pretty good with the violent swings in volatility that we were able to manage through that process across all of our products globally and not be highly surprised. That goes from the Lehman bankruptcy to the AIG issues to swings in certain securities of 25% in a day. And you can imagine what it's like to manage through that process. And I think for our people here, I think it's very important to note it was an unbelievable thing to watch the people accomplish the WaMu acquisition, managing the portfolios, a lot of these same people were dealing with clients on mortgages and issues trying to do the right thing for clients every day. So it makes you really proud to watch what the people here are able to accomplish and I think it also portends very well what can be accomplished in the future. I will also mention on the Treasury package, because I know it's in the back of your minds, we were presented with a package from the government and this is the way that JPMorgan saw it. The United States Government is trying to do some very powerful things to fix the situation. And a lot of people can come up with a whole bunch of different programs, but they had one, and I think what they're doing in this package, plus all the prior things that have been done, is very powerful and you will start to see some effect. So we really saw this as doing something which is very good for the system. It is equally true if you said, well, they're asymmetric benefits for -- it could be a negative for JPMorgan versus competition. That may very well be true, but we did not think that JPMorgan should be selfish or parochial and try to stop what's good for the system, because it might be mildly bad for us relative to some of our competitors. So we hope it will work. There's $25 billion of capital. If it comes in the door, we hope to find ways to be able to use it to benefit our shareholders and to continue to be there for our clients. I do want to point out that we are there for our clients. Commercial loans are up 18%. The Investment Banking loans are way up, and a lot of the things we do every day, we are trying to do the best we can to be in business for our clients, even in some categories where if you ask the question if you borrow at today's marginal cost and lent out at today's yields in home equity/auto, you are probably losing money. But we still try to stay in business in the right way for people who walk into our branches or deal with our bankers. So we will stop there and open the floor to any questions you all may have.
JAMIE DIMON: We've had some gain in prime broker, and I'm going to say if you look at total balance has been able to go something like 25% over the quarter. So Bear is performing the way we expect, but I don't remember the specific numbers of what it did in the equity.
JAMIE DIMON: A small net positive, but not a big net positive.
JAMIE DIMON: That number alone, if it stays where it is today, could cost us $100 million a month in that business. We don't expect it to stay there. And obviously there are actions we can take that can reduce that over time.
JAMIE DIMON: It's a non voting preferred, so we don't expect the government to get involved in our business. But it is clear that the government would like us use the capital to facilitate clients to make loans and stuff like that, and we want to do that, too, so I think we have a common interest in this.
JAMIE DIMON: Again, I don't think the government is telling us what to do with the capital. When you say leveragable, I think you can use it. We fully expect to use some of it to do a good job for our shareholders. The government guarantee on the debt side just makes it easier for banks to roll over their liabilities and some banks are having trouble doing that. JPMorgan was not.
JAMIE DIMON: I think if you are a bank that's filling a hole, obviously you can't do that. If you are a bank that is not filling a hole, obviously you can do some of that. But we just got it. We haven't even got it yet, so we're just sitting here making sure we do it right. And obviously it will relate to the environment you see going ahead. It's very important for us, just like I think it's very important for the government, that all of these institutions be able to weather whatever happens coming forward.
JAMIE DIMON: Look, I don't think it's highly relevant to us, honestly. We're down to smaller numbers now, and so the answer is probably not, but we'll see how the details come out and figure out then. But I think the TARP facility, when it comes out, may very well help the market and that will help anyone who wants to trade those markets, because you will have real prices, real discovery and real ability to how you manage your own assets and capital.
JAMIE DIMON: I think we've been clear right from the beginning, there were no valuation reserves ever in the Bear Stearns deal. All those assets came over and were marked.
JAMIE DIMON: At fair value. There were reserves for litigation, severance, a whole bunch of stuff like that, but they were our best estimate. There's nothing left over from Bear Stearns. If you said what would your losses have been in mortgages this quarter had you not done the Bear Stearns deal, my guess is about 40% of that came from Bear Stearns.
JAMIE DIMON: I don't know. I think the paperwork is not finished on that. And obviously, we are going to read that very carefully.
JAMIE DIMON: I would be willing to use it for anything that made sense to JPMorgan shareholders.
JAMIE DIMON: There's no Fed backup. The Fed is financing $30 billion of assets and we're taking the first $1.1 billion or whatever the number is of loss there. Again, we've been very consistent. We think the Fed is going to get all their money back and we expect to get a little bit of our first loss note back, too. But I don't know. They're managing that. It's up to them and it depends how they manage it over time. They make their own reports, by the
JAMIE DIMON: It's about what it started at. And it's obviously bounced all over the place in the last month.
JAMIE DIMON: We have made no changes to our accounting. I think what the SEC guideline sent out is that, in a market where there's no trading, that you've got to use your judgment and models and stuff like that. We've made no change in ours. I think the European banks -- we are already allowed if we want to move from a trading account to a health and maturity account. We took you all through that last time. We did do that with a little bit of stuff. We put up a lot more reserves, not less, when we did that. As a matter of fact, we wanted more reserves. I think they said the banks can do that themselves in Europe now.
JAMIE DIMON: We think we are going to be fine in those risks, but we just want to point it out. There's really two things, to simplify a little bit. One is trading, honestly all of us thought that if you ever saw a -- we used to call it the major dealer exit, that it would be very tough on trading. It was but I think it was -- I think the street was able to get through that rather quickly and easily. But there are still some open issues relating to that, but not big. And the second is we were a huge financing tri-party agent and we have collateral against that and some of that collateral we have to liquidate, some of that belongs to some other people. We think that will all sort out.
JAMIE DIMON: So first of all, keep in mind that we already had eliminated double cycle billing and we had already eliminated off-us pricing, this is where we price -- that we changed your pricing because of FICO score changes or something like that. So two of the biggest things that people complain about, we already don't do. So put them to the side. And that cost us money. I forgot the number. We disclosed here at one point, it took like
JAMIE DIMON: So the other stuff, and there's a whole bunch of stuff out there. I would put in the category of it could be significant, so any one change on its own could be hundreds of millions of dollars, or something like that in total they could be well over $1 billion. But there are actions that would take place that would that would change a lot of that. So for example, if you can't reprice certain loans, you are not going to make certain types of loans. If you have to have people pay off teaser rate loans last on a series of loans, we're not going to make teaser rate loans. So a lot of that stuff I think competitively it will cause kind of changes in profits in the short run, but not in the long run. It will change your prices. If you cannot price for risk, you are going to charge everybody else more.
JAMIE DIMON: We already have, but honestly, some of the fees or outstandings we were going to pull back on weren't that profitable anyway. So we're going to run the business for profit. If outstandings go down $10 billion, so be it.
JAMIE DIMON: Nothing other than that.
JAMIE DIMON: Let me explain. So Corporate has a $100 billion portfolio, and that portfolio is for interest rate exposures, for collateral reasons, to manage the balance sheet of the company. We are moving some of that portfolio slowly and carefully into higher yielding assets. Because remember, we're here for shareholders. And some of these assets we think are going to give great returns to shareholders over time. So it's not any great rush, but those assets will include a little bit of AAA CLO, a little bit of bank preferred, a little bit of Alt-A, a little bit of CMBS. And we're not going to do it ad hoc, we're just going to do it over time. So those that they move were the same type of assets they were buying. And they were moved to fair value, so there's no benefit.
JAMIE DIMON: Yes, most of those will continue to be marked to market in the treasury portfolio. So you will see a little more volatility in Corporate, because more of the assets there are being held in a trading portfolio, because they have -- for a whole bunch of reasons they have to be, but again, like we said, we are here for shareholder results. And if we have to take a little bit more risk to do a good thing for shareholders, we're willing to take a little more volatility.
JAMIE DIMON: They were really, really good.
JAMIE DIMON: Honestly, it was an exceptional performance. Some areas I think the rising tide lifted all boats, so I think you'll see a lot of trading desks in certain currencies and certain rates where the rising tide lifted all boats. In other areas, our people just did an exceptional job. Emerging markets, we were hedged for downturns on the equity side. We were prepared and positioned for markets going down, so we benefited from that. And we're not taking big bets on it, but it was a pretty good performance. Again, we don't expect that to repeat, though.
JAMIE DIMON: We think in the market share side on the wholesale side, yes. You see that in TSS. We think in Private Bank the answer would be yes. Retail, the answer is no. Part of the reason, we weren't competing aggressively for funds, nor are we in areas where you had this big flight to quality. So I think if you were in California or Florida and you were strong, you had a big inflow. We weren't in California and Florida, so we weren't the beneficiary of flight to quality in California and Florida -- but we think we're probably gaining a little bit of share. I think deposits in the last month are up $100 billion in total. That number may be off a little bit, but it's a huge number.
JAMIE DIMON: Let me step back. Prime/LIBOR has a huge negative effect we took on Card. It's got a modest beneficial affect across other businesses, so that's not a big deal and it doesn't affect -- directly affect the origination business. The origination business, and I think it's true for a lot of people in the industry, Meredith, that people have gone back to old fashioned 80% LTV, real verified income, more disciplined appraisals, and then in some areas they won't even go to 85% LTV because of expected home decreases, so we are not at 80% in California, Nevada, or Florida.
JAMIE DIMON: We're at 65%. So that's why it's down. I think it's true for us and everybody else. Almost everything being originated is eligible for Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, or FHA. So therefore you have this great reduction for us and other people in origination. Obviously the quality of that stuff is going to be much higher.
JAMIE DIMON: No, I think the answer is probably yes, but we'll never really know. And so if everyone pulls credit out of California, obviously it will accelerate the depreciation of homes in California and make it harder and scarier for people to provide credit. Let me just make a general comment about a crisis like this. One of the things that happens, which I think the government is focusing on, is there are a lot of individual actors. I am talking about you as investors, banks as providers of credit, individuals, small businesses, large businesses, all start to take actions that are rational for them as an individual or corporation, but in total, can cause exactly what you are talking about. And that's one of the things that the government is trying to reverse. It's not just the banks. It's the individuals who invest in banks, it's people who provide capital to other financial institutions who are pulling it out or moving their money back overseas. And so you do see a little bit of that, and they are trying to arrest that. That is the one thing that's got people most scared and they are trying to stop it. Like I said before, I think what the government is doing is pretty powerful medicine. I say the governments around the world is pretty powerful medicine, and I think will you start to see some beneficial effect of that in the next couple weeks.
JAMIE DIMON: We're not big speculators, but we are buying slightly more risky assets and we're growing our businesses everywhere, so we're not panicking. Credit cards were up, credit card receivables are up. We are not pulling out of California. We're still going there. We're still marketing. Obviously we try and modify what's going on, but we are not going to say, "yahoo, this is over", and extend credit like we did without fear. If you are not fearful, you're crazy.
JAMIE DIMON: We know you are. We're waiting for you to reverse your position.
JAMIE DIMON: So leverage loans we did, and I'll give you some numbers now. Ready? Prime loans is not really applicable. Securities are marked in the high 50s. Alt-A performing loans about mid 70s, non-performing loans, 40s. That's loans. Alt-A securities, high 20s. Subprime mid-30s. CMBS loans mid-80s. Securities mid-70s, that's all we are going to give you because it's competitive information.
JAMIE DIMON: It's mostly vintage, Bill.
JAMIE DIMON: We may change our reporting of that and combine so we don't cause this confusion going forward. One of this things I should mention -- Mike mentioned it, it's when we look at the mortgage business, by the way, that we kind of looked at the $12 billion ongoing, it's trading, moving, that's what we need to do to service clients, properly marked, you shouldn't see huge -- obviously risk in trading but it should be back to more normal kind of risk. And there's $6 billion, it's marked, but put it in as kind of liquidating, very hard to trade. There's certain residuals you can't trade at all. And it's marked down to we're going to get -- I would believe we are going to get very substantial returns from 10 to 20%, (inaudible) as we liquidate it using fairly bad assumptions. So we don't like it, but it's not that big a deal any more.
JAMIE DIMON: I just think you should be very cautious. I'm guessing what the environment is going to be. So this crisis isn't over, so we are just guessing, like you can guess on your own. We don't know anything that you don't know. We are just guessing that it still can be pretty tough out there for awhile. You might have some more markdowns that -- Mike had mentioned that we have really healthy loan losses, $77 billion of loans I think the number is. We have almost 4% up against that. That's historically high, but it's very idiosyncratic. If one big company fails, that could be a huge loss for us, so we're just prepared for it to be a little tougher in the Investment Bank. We hope to make some money, but we are not going to count on it for now.
JAMIE DIMON: I wouldn't be shocked if we make a lot of money one of these quarters either, by the way.
JAMIE DIMON: A little bit, a little bit in alt-A, maybe a little bit in some of the CMBS stuff. Remember, TARP
JAMIE DIMON: -- just the anticipation might cause some of that. Surprisingly we haven't really seen anything in agencies. CMBS, which spreads are still damn near the highs and we think those are probably very good buys. I would expect one day, we're going to wake up, those snap in dramatically. And then we'll probably be mad at ourselves we didn't buy more.
JAMIE DIMON: It was realized in the AFS portfolio. There was some trading losses in there that -MICHAEL CAVANAGH: Some trading losses on some non-interest rate products and just changing coupon trades in some of the mortgages on there that were realized gains.
JAMIE DIMON: I don't have the number handy, Glenn, and we haven't really talked through it exactly.
JAMIE DIMON: Remember, it includes -- the way we understand it, it includes CP, promissory notes, maturing debt, all unsecured, holding company and bank, so it's a pretty big number. And it's 125% of that.
JAMIE DIMON: We'll get back to you.
JAMIE DIMON: I think the second you see a levelization of charge-offs, with some certainty going forward, that you don't need any additions to reserves. Keep going until all the questions are asked.
JAMIE DIMON: Okay. So once you -- once we decide to go in the program I was thinking, can we have $50 billion? So think of it this way. Obviously by the time you get to 9%, you will probably want to have paid it off. And the warrants are equal to the value you are getting. So in our case, they are going to get warrants, the way it's currently written, 10-year warrants on $3.75 billion of stock. And those warrants are worth -- you can estimate at $1.2 billion, whatever you come up with, which is an additional cost on the $25 billion. So it's 5%, plus the way I look at it, a year, plus another 5% for the full term. You just monetize the cost of the warrants, so it's not bad money that way. There is a way if you refinance it sooner, and you've got to refinance it with real Tier 1 capital, that you can eliminate half the warrants, and we'll deal with that in due course. That to me becomes purely a financial decision, to do that or not do that, but the government made this part of it not an unattractive thing so that people can get the capital, use the capital, and hopefully do some good with the capital.
JAMIE DIMON: It's not the shares. It's warrants for $3.75 billion worth of stock.
JAMIE DIMON: You could do your own share calculation. The market value of those warrants would be something like $1.2 billion or $1.3 billion. You can use your own model.
JAMIE DIMON: Use your own model. I'm simply saying, think of that, it's only -- of the whole $25 billion, it's another 5%, maybe 6%. So if you spread it over the first five years, of the 5% of money, your money is costing you 6.5%. It's still cheaper than most companies can raise money at today. And it's real Tier 1, so it's very cheap Tier 1. So to that extent, it's not a bad economic transaction.
JAMIE DIMON: There is a way to reduce them at one point, but you could argue that's a lot of people that won't want to, because that's cheaper capital than you could otherwise get, if they think they can do something with it.
JAMIE DIMON: It's all Tier 1 capital, yes.
JAMIE DIMON: The warrants are not Tier 1 capital. They are just a dilution on the balance sheet, I think.
JAMIE DIMON: I think what they said is 10 basis points in that. And think of that as an operating account guarantee. I think the real point of that wasn't for JPMorgan, it's for really smaller community banks and stuff who do a lot of business, small business, middle market, and they don't want those people to be afraid that their operating accounts are at risk.
JAMIE DIMON: It doesn't mean anything to us, Ron, either way, whether we do it or don't.
JAMIE DIMON: Nancy, I don't really think so. And I think that one day everything will have normalized again. It might be three years out or five years out. I think what they really wanted to do -- and I don't know how long they worked on this, so I wouldn't assume it was just three days. I do think they had to do something relative to the rest of the world. If you were in their shoes, you would look and it and say, if the rest of the world is guaranteeing deposits and the United States is not, the rest of the world -- you might create other consequences. But I agree with you, making policy on the run is a very hard thing to do and always has these huge unintended consequences, which is really hard to forecast or have any foresight on at all. But I think one day it will normalize and it will make raising capital for banks more expensive for banks. We'll go back to a more normal world and people will probably spend a lot more attention on credit, which they should.
JAMIE DIMON: I think that one of the consequences is that this program obviously helps the weaker more than it helps the strong. And I think I mentioned at the beginning that, if you don't want to be parochial and selfish, as long as it's really materially helping the system, we all should be in favor of it. We can sit around the table and argue all day long, we would have been better off, and it's true -- you're not better off if the system goes down. But I don't think the intent on the treasury, I think they're very conscious of -- they don't intend to hold up failing banks. And you haven't seen them do that. What you have seen them do is be pretty aggressive to try to get failing banks in the hands of good owners. So they are going to have, throughout this program, the devil will be in the details how they manage it. We'll all be looking at how they really manage it going forward. And we'll be second guessing them, too, at one point.
JAMIE DIMON: Thank you very much. We'll talk to you soon.

MIKE CAVANAGH, CFO, JPMORGAN CHASE & CO.: Great. Good morning everybody. Thanks for joining Jamie and I. We will go through the usual slide presentation that's available on the web. I refer you to slide 20 which gives the usual forward-looking comments disclaimers for you to read at your own leisure. With that, let us get started on the overall results on slide one, the highlights here. So we had $3.6 billion in net income in quarter. That's earnings per share of $0.82 on revenues of $28.8 billion. I won't spend too much time talking about where the results came from here because we will go through it business by business, but obviously it was great strength in the Investment Bank, and strong performance in the Asset Management, Commercial Bank and Retail Banking Businesses, as well as very strong results in our Corporate investment portfolio. The backdrop again, though, is that credit costs remain elevated. You will see that on various degrees of flattening and charge offs or slowing pace of increase, but nonetheless continue to be at high levels. We added $2 billion to the consumer credit reserves, though, to bring the total credit reserves to $31.5 billion dollars , which is obviously a very strong number both for the firm and each line of business. I will point that out as we go through. Overall reserve to loans for the firm of 5.3%. Capital - very proud of the capital level of the Company. Tier 1 common through the retention of those earnings, growth through $100 billion to $101 billion with a Tier 1 common ratio of 8.2% and a Tier 1 capital ratio of 10.2%. Obviously, very strong capital levels. Slide two has everything I just described on it. I will skip that and take us to slide three, the Investment Bank. Here let's walk through the results in the Investment Bank. You see the circled number, the net income of $1.9 billion on revenues of a $7.5 billion for the business overall. I will just make one clarifying statement up front that a couple of the items you have been focused on in the past, together had an immaterial impact on the overall profit, the combination of two items. One is the tightening of credit spreads, a spread on JPMorgan's name and counter-party credit spread, DVA CVA as it's known, netted together for a modest net negative, and then we had gains of approximately $400 million, mostly realized on those legacy leverage lending and mortgage positions, mostly leveraged loans. Moving through, putting that aside let's move through the underlying real dynamics of the business. So investment banking fee line $1.7 billion, up a bit year-over-year and off some from the record quarter that we had last quarter, second quarter, where we booked something like $2.2 billion of investment banking fees. We maintained the number one year-to-date rankings across all the major capital rate and categories, so the Investment Banking franchise is doing quite well and continues to do so. The Fixed Income Markets line, revenues of $5 billion, and that obviously has the gains on leveraged loans that I talked about, bringing the total value of leveraged loans now carried on the books down to a market value of $2.2 billion or carried at less than $0.40 on the dollar. That's a 26% reduction from last quarter. So, we are likely not to be talking about that any more from this stage. And then, strong performance across most of the other products, really, in the Fixed Income Markets area. Equity Markets, similar story, $941 million worth of revenues, particular strength ongoing in the Prime Services segment there. The last thing I will comment on in the Investment Bank is credit costs. You can see the credit costs of $379 million over on the left, and the explanation there is that that is charge offs of $750 million, partially offset by release in allowance related to particular loans that got marked down in the quarter, for which we previously held our marks in the form of reserves. That's just a geography swing leaving us with well marked on a net basis between reserves and marks on those loans. But that was a release of $371 million to get you to the $379 million net number. Overall though, leaves us with 8.44% at the end of the quarter of reserve to loans there. Moving on to Retail Financial Services on the next slide, some of the drivers here, top half of the page is the deposit taking side, the Retail Bank. Here, as we said, I will point you to the circled number, average deposits $339.6 billion, up obviously versus a year ago, given Washington Mutual transaction this time a year ago, and declined as expected by about $8 billion from last quarter, as we let high-rate, high-cost Washington Mutual CDs, one year CDs, are rolling off mostly in the third and fourth quarter coming up. Everything else in the branch production side, we still have underlying good growth in the Retail Banking franchise, inclusive of WaMu and away from WaMu as well, and the WaMu integration continues to go quite well, with the last conversion happening in a couple of weeks here. So everything healthy and on track in the Retail Bank. Consumer Lending side down at the bottom of the page. Total firm-wide originations and renewals of credit total about $140 billion in the quarter, and $46 billion of that is what you see down in the bottom of this page in the retail side. That's $37 billion or so of mortgage loan originations, about flat year-over-year and down a bit quarter-over-quarter. Remember the real dynamic in that business is our exit of the broker channel in the past 12 months helping drive some of those numbers, replaced by activities more directly originated by ourselves. And then next is auto originations. You see about $7 billion of auto originations, we have done well in terms of market share in that business in the prime side, and particular strength this quarter with the Cash for Clunkers program. So moving to the next slide, slide five, for the income statement for Retail Financial Services. We will just take this in two pieces. So as you see in the middle of the left-hand side, the Retail Bank revenues of about $4.6 billion, up substantially from year ago given Washington Mutual in particular. We had profits of $1.043 billion in the quarter. So very profitable business in Retail Banking, consistent and up a little bit from last quarter. Then the other side of RFS is Consumer Lending at the bottom of the page, and driven by the very high level of credit costs that I will go through in the next slide of $3.8 billion which includes some additions, about $1.4 billion addition to loan loss reserves, we ended up having an after-tax loss of about $1 billion in consumer lending. So moving to the slide on the credit portfolios in Home Lending, let me just talk through that for a second. So here, slide six, I will start on the upper left with some of the overall commentary here. As we said last quarter, and then a month ago at a conference, we continue to see initial signs of stability in the consumer, early bucket delinquency trends, but we are not ready to declare that that's a sustained trend, but it is continuing to be what we actually observe. Another overall comment is that as far as the impact of foreclosure moratorium, the trial mods which have been very active in doing, and just the overall extension of processing of REO through the courts, those things are obviously having an effect on overall delinquency stats. But just want to make it clear that we are doing everything we can to stay on top of the income statements, recognizing losses through charge-offs and adding to reserves without regard for the impact that those factors would be causing in the overall delinquency stats. So with that, moving over to the left hand side you see the actual charge-offs for the quarter in the circle there, that totals up to about $2.1 billion this quarter across these three portfolios, down a touch from last quarter. We obviously measure that in terms of expected lifetime losses on that portfolio, and have added $1.1 billion that is put on the books in the form of a loan loss reserve as opposed to an incremental mark. So that is $1.4 billion -- $1.1 billion of the $1.4 billion loan loss addition in RFS or in Consumer Lending in the quarter. And we bolstered reserves here by about $600 million. On the revenue side, the dynamics here we continue to see, end-of-period outstandings circled at $144 billion, trending lower from the year ago and last quarter. But the overall market we believe is the factor driving the 6% year-over-year decline, and that obviously factors into the revenue side. So that, together with the credit costs, gets you to the loss in the business, obviously high level of stress on the losses in the Washington Mutual portfolio. So losses in this business we expect to continue as we said through next year, no different from what we said before there. On the Commercial Banking business, page eight, you see profits of $341 million, up 9% year-over-year. Continued good dynamics in this business. Obviously, credit trends are up, but revenues are up year-over-year, largely due to the impact of Washington Mutual. But at $1.5 billion, that along with very good expense management, gives us the earnings power to absorb a normalized credit environment. So you can see on the credit cost line, total $355 million of credit costs, that is on higher charge offs you see circled down on the left, 111 basis points of charge off rates for the business, up year-over-year and quarter-over-quarter, but consistent with what we have talked about in this kind of economy, these portfolios credit is going to normalize. We end the quarter with more than 3, at 3% reserve to loans, which we think is very well reserved for the business. So a disappointing revenue decline in WSS. TS down a little on the revenue side, and that drives the overall profit number of about $300 million in the business. Asset Management on slide 10, net income here of $430 million, up year-over-year, 23% on revenues of $2.1 billion, which are up 6% year-over-year. And you can see the spread across the various businesses, Private Bank, Institutional, and so forth. Really, continue to do well in the business here. Assets under management, $1.3 trillion, that is all the market level impacts on the business together with nice positive inflows of $113 billion for the past year and continued inflows of $34 billion in the past quarter. And investment performance continues to be strong and that, of course, is the necessary ingredient in this business. So overall, things continue to be doing well in the Asset Management business. And then lastly, on the income statement, is the Corporate Segment. I will spend a minute on this, page 11. So breaking it up into the pieces, you see in the box in the upper left, the net income box, so net income of $88 million in Private Equity, that's on revenues of $155 million, the first time we've had some positive valuations in Private Equity in a little while. The next line is important. That's Corporate, that's everything else inclusive of the treasury business and the corporate investment portfolio. Here, obviously a very strong $1.3 billion of net income. That $900 million is obviously a very strong number in the quarter. We try to adjust on the delinquency side -- we keep all mortgage modifications and delinquencies throughout the trial process. That's actually driven up our delinquencies, not down. And Mike may remember what that number was, something like 20%.
MIKE CAVANAGH: Yes, 20% to 30% higher depending on the portfolio.
MIKE CAVANAGH: That's in the total provisioning line. We took $750 million worth of charge downs. So carrying value of loans written down by $750 million. But on a loan-by-loan basis, many of those loans entered the quarter already having reserves up against them. So on a net of reserves basis, they were already on average carried at $0.60 on the dollar. So it's just a geography swing. We like -- on a particular, hypothetically, we like $0.60 on the dollar and we have a charge off event. So we charge the carrying value down by $0.40 and release the $0.40 of reserves we had. That's all running through the credit costs line. It's a release of allowance for loan losses.
JAMIE DIMON: It is different for every single product. It is hard to say, but a benchmark with 1x before the crisis, it got as high as 6x. And has come back to 2x. But it is really different for every product. 1x may have been unnaturally low and never come back to 1x, but the competitors are back which is a good thing for the industry. There is much more competition today and people competing both in the flow and reducing spreads.
JAMIE DIMON: Let me just talk to big picture, if you look at the FSA has spoken about, or the Financial Stability Board. We don't yet have the fed, the fed or the treasury put out their own guidelines, but most of those guidelines are global. If you at the pay policies of JPMorgan Chase, we have followed them. We don't have parachutes or change of control or special severance packages. We already pay people substantial amounts of their compensation in deferred comp and stock -- stock options we had called back for, I'm going to call, bad behavior and things like that. We already asked the senior people of the Company, the operating committee and the executive committee to keep a lot of their stock they ever get issued to them as long as they have their job, so they become substantial shareholders over time. We always looked at long-term sustained performance realizing that the rising tide will sell boats and the sinking tide can sinkhole boats. We have looked at the contribution people make to building a great franchise at JPMorgan, and that includes recruiting, how they treat clients, systems, not just financial results. We maintain those standards and we think have done it right and fair and continue to do what we're doing. Industries have to pay for performance over time, and we are committed to treating each individual, each individual properly.
JAMIE DIMON: Let me mention one thing about comp because it hasn't been. We also call back the operating committee for any reason. We can call back for almost any reason from the operating committee members. So, on dividend we want to give clarity. Obviously, shareholders rely on it, going into a bleak environment with the potential it could get even worse. The first goal became to protect the Company, but once we are convinced that is gone, we want to reestablish the dividend. We're always said about stock buy backs that that's on opportunistic thing. We buy back when we think it is cheap or the best thing to do with our capital. And we're not going to buy back when we think the stock is expensive or have better uses for capital. It will be unrelated to dividend, because dividend is a long-term decision to make for shareholders.
JAMIE DIMON: Look we are not -- what we see, you actually all see pretty much what we see, and there seems to be the stability in the environment in terms of consumer spending, confidence, in terms of delinquencies, a little bit of improvement in home price. The only thing I'd say anecdotally which we do get very consistently now is that business, small business, middle market, large corporate, the kind of poised and waiting to see the recovery is taking hold. So they have plans, financial plans and growth plans, so to me it would be a good sign if that's true because maybe people get a little more comfortable, they'll start making a little more risk and making more investments in the future.
JAMIE DIMON: The first thing is to get our own model right, own products and services and make sure we adjust to the new laws and things like that. Our marketing budget so far for 2010 in Cards is up by several hundred million dollars, it is not down. But we will spend that money when we feel we will get a good return on it.
JAMIE DIMON: Almost every business is making investments.
